clinical_study.brief_title: Inferior Vena Cava Index in Patients Undergoing Liver Resection
clinical_study.official_title: Does Inferior Vena Cava Collapsibility Correlate With Fluid Regimen and Outcome in Patients Undergoing Liver Resection?

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study was to evaluate whether IVC index measured intraoperatively was affected by fluid administration and could add any helpful information about the hemodynamics during hepatic resection. In addition, the investigators evaluated whether IVC index was somehow correlated with the risk of postoperative complication.

primary_outcome.measure: to investigate the influence of the liver resection on hemodynamic status in terms of hemodynamic indexes changes

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients with liver tumors candidate to hepatectomy

intervention.intervention_name: IVC diameters evaluation by intraoperative ultrasound
intervention.description: Out of consecutive patients who underwent hepatectomy for primary and secondary liver tumors, patients in whom IVC diameters were intraoperatively measured for clinical reasons were retrospectively selected and analyzed
intervention.arm_group_label: Patients with liver tumors candidate to hepatectomy

study_pop.textblock: Patients underwent liver resection for primary and secondary liver disease

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients who underwent hepatectomy for primary and secondary liver tumors
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients with tumoral thrombosis or full tumoral involvement/compression of IVC were excluded. Patients unresectable at laparotomy for any extra-hepatic or intrahepatic reason and patients previously submitted to hepatectomy were not included
